The  proposed  Punjab  Devolved  Social  Services  Program  (PDSSP) 
comprises  two  program  loans  and  a  grant  to  support  critical  reforms, 
institutional  strengthening,  capacity  building,  and  partnership  building  in 
Punjab’s  devolved  social  services  in  the  areas  of  health,  education,  and 
water supply and sanitation (WSS).

Pakistan  experienced  good  economic  growth  in  the  1980s  but  generally 
performed  poorly  in  the  1990s  when  poverty  was  exacerbated.  Recently, 
economic  performance  has  improved;  however,  Pakistan  remains  a  poor 
country with extremely low social indicators. Punjab is the largest province 
of Pakistan with an estimated population of 83 million or 56% of the total 
population. The incidence of poverty in the province was around 34.1% in 
2001/02,  much  higher  than  28.2%  estimated  in  1993/94.  The  urban-rural 
gap is significant: poverty has increased more rapidly in rural areas, from 
31.9%  in  1993/94  to  about  37.0%  in  2001/02.  Inequitable  provision  of 
social  services,  as  reflected  by  the  upper-income  groups  commanding 
greater  access  than  households  with  lower  incomes,  has  led  to  an 
increase  in  poverty  of  opportunity.  As  a  result,  Punjab’s  social  indicators 
fall  far  short  of  its  economic  development,  as  reflected  by  low  literacy 
rates; high infant, child, and maternal mortality rates; high susceptibility to 
communicable diseases; very low proportion of deliveries by trained birth 
attendants; high disparity among income and gender groups in access to 
social  services;  and  inadequate  conditions  of  sanitation  and  solid  waste 
management. A key reason in the inability to reduce poverty and improve 
the social indicators in the country in general, including Punjab, has been 
the poor performance of the overly centralized and inefficient bureaucracy. 
Local-level government agencies have been incapable of delivering basic 
social services for a variety of reasons, including lack of proper incentives, 
understaffing, corruption, inadequate capacity, and lack of participation by 
the beneficiaries.

Responding  to  the  chronic  failure  to  deliver  the  basic  social  services 
needed to reduce poverty, the Government of Pakistan (the Government) 
initiated  a  sweeping  and  complex  reform  program  in  2001  designed  to 
devolve  the  authority  and  responsibility  for  social  services  to  the  local 
level.  Under  the  Local  Government  Ordinance  of  2001,  the  provincial 
governments  have  transferred  primary  responsibility  of  major  social 
service  delivery  functions,  including  education,  health,  and  WSS,  to  local 
government  institutions.  This  change  has  resulted  in  redefinition  of  roles 
and responsibilities at the provincial and local government levels, including 
planning, financing, execution of services, and monitoring. 
 
Overall, the Government of Punjab (PG) is short of resources in relation to 
its  large  socioeconomic  needs.  At  the  moment,  the  fiscal  structure  in 
Pakistan is heavily skewed in favor of the Government, with provinces and 
local  governments  both  heavily  reliant  on  fiscal  transfers  from  the 
Government.  In  response,  the  Government  has  prepared  a  Poverty 
Reduction  Strategy  Paper  (PRSP)  with  the  provinces  having  developed 
similar  province-level  PRSPs,  which  set  out  a  comprehensive  policy 
reform  agenda  to  break  the  vicious  cycle  of  poverty.  Punjab’s  PRSP  (P-
PRSP)  aims

growth;  improve  the  delivery  of  public  services,  especially  basic  social 
services; and address vulnerabilities. PG is refocusing its expenditures on 
pro-poor  sectors.  PG  has  started  preparing  a  medium-term  budgetary 
framework  to  prioritize  its  expenditures  since  fiscal  year  (FY)  2003/04, 
which  needs  to  be  strengthened  and  expanded  to  cover  all  sectors.  PG

The  overall  goal  of  PDSSP  is  to  achieve  progress  on  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) related to poverty, gender, education, health, 
and WSS. PDSSP’s objective is to strengthen devolved social services for 
a  more  equitable,  efficient,  effective,  and  sustainable  delivery  of  social 
services  in  line  with  the  Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  2001 
(PLGO). In order to achieve the goal and objective, it will be necessary to 
support  reforms  and  capacity  building  to  help  (i) expand  coverage  of 
health  services  (especially  for  women  and  children),  increase  school 
enrollment  rates,  and  improve  access  to  WSS  facilities;  (ii) move  away 
from provincially-driven to demand-driven programs that are identified and 
implemented  by  LGs  in  line  with  P-PRSP,  medium-term  budgetary 
framework,  and  provincial  strategic  plans  and  guidelines  to  achieve 
MDGs;  and  (iii)  enhance  the  capacity  of  LGs  to  assume  new  roles  and 
responsibilities in social services as envisaged under the PLGO, including 
participatory planning, implementation, and monitoring and evaluation.

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

 
The Government of Pakistan (the Government) has been pursuing an ambitious reform 
2. 
agenda  over  the  last  4  years  aimed  at  putting  the  economy  on  a  stronger  and  more  stable 
footing. With the rescheduling of external debt and a more proactive debt management strategy 
in place, record levels of exports, lower interest rates, a buoyant stock market, and a continued 
policy of privatization, gross domestic product (GDP) growth has been increasing, estimated at 
about 6.4% in fiscal year (FY) 2004, and projected to rise to 6.6% in FY2005. The high growth 
has  been  accompanied  by  relatively  stable  prices,  lower  debt  service  payments,  manageable 
fiscal deficits, an external account surplus, and unprecedented high levels of foreign exchange 
reserves.  Several  factors  are  cited  for  this  economic  recovery,  including  economic  and 
governance  reforms,  stabilization  policy  of  the  Government  in  the  past  few  years,  global 
developments  after  September  11,  2001,  and  positive  developments  on  the  political  and 
regional  fronts.  However,  despite  these  positive  developments,  investment  activity  has  been 
sluggish due to excess capacities and cautious behavior of investors. With recent improvements 
in  regional,  political,  and  business  environments,  officials  are  now  optimistic  that  investments 
will  increase.  Barring  any  major  policy  reversal  and  political  and  international  upheavals, 
Pakistan’s economy is poised for high economic growth in the coming years.1 
  
3. 
 In spite of the relatively optimistic economic prospects, Pakistan remains a poor country 
with very low social indicators that are among the worst in the region. The Government is aware 
that  poverty,  illiteracy,  and  ill  health  among  its  population  are  a  major  hindrance  to  economic 
progress  and  a  source  of  social  instability.  Accordingly,  the  Government  has  undertaken  a 
sweeping and complex reform program designed to devolve authority and responsibility to the 
local level and prepared a Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP).  
 
 The  devolution  provides  a  framework  for  three  major  reforms,  namely  political, 
4. 
administrative,  and  fiscal.  By  political  reforms,  the  Government  created  a  third  tier  of  local 
government (LG) at the district level and below through local-level elected representatives. The 
administrative  and  management  powers  were  decentralized  including  human  resource 
management for 12 important sectors including social services and infrastructure. The political 
and  administrative  decentralization  was  backed  by  fiscal  reforms  in  the  shape  of  provision  of 
block grants to the LGs, and authority to raise revenue through levy of local taxes. 
 
Prepared after extensive consultations with all stakeholders, the PRSP revolves around

four  basic  strategies:  (i) achieving  high  and  broad-based  economic  growth,  (ii) improving 
governance and consolidating devolution, (iii) developing human capital and efficient delivery of

83 million  or  56%  of  the  total  population  of  Pakistan.  Given  the  size  of  the  population  in  the 
province, the quality of the delivery of social services by the Government of Punjab (PG) affects 
over  half  of  the  country's  population.  To  reverse  the  trend  and  sharpen  the  focus  on  poverty 
reduction  at  the  provincial  level,  a  Punjab  PRSP  (P-PRSP)  was  developed  in  2003  in  the 
context of the national PRSP.  
 
8. 
Punjab  PRSP.  P-PRSP  aims  to  improve  governance,  reform  fiscal  and  financial 
management,  create  a  supportive  environment  for  private-sector  led  growth,  improve  the 
delivery  of  public  services  (especially  basic  social  services),  and  address  vulnerabilities. 
Governance  improvements  include  civil  service  reforms  and  strengthening  devolution  and 
planning  processes  to  improve  efficiency,  accountability,  and  service  orientation.  Planning

implementation,  and  monitoring;  strengthening  provincial  and  LG  capacities;  and  preparing 
medium-term strategies under the medium-term budgetary framework (MTBF), which needs to 
be  strengthened.  As  the  largest  province,  the  successful  implementation  and  sustainability  of 
the P-PRSP and its pro-poor expenditures on devolved social services are crucial for Pakistan 
to  move  toward  overall  reduction  in  poverty  and  achieving  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs). PG has requested long-term support from ADB for its devolved social services.2 The 
program framework is in Appendix 1.

2. 

Devolution to Local Governments  

 
14. 
Under  the  centralized  system,  social  sectors  were  poorly  planned,  administered,  and 
monitored;  hence,  improvement  in  social  indicators  was  slower  than  planned.  Planning  was  a 
top-down  approach  with  hardly  any  involvement  of  citizens  or  communities  in  planning, 
implementing,  or  monitoring  social  services.  The  public  sector  had  assumed  the  role  of 
purchaser as well as provider of services with very little partnership with the not-for-profit or for-
profit  private  sector.  Centralized  planning  and  management  created  a  number  of 
shortcomings—inappropriate  location  of  facilities,  staff  absenteeism,  short-working  hours,  low 
quality  of  services,  and  lack  of  consumer  satisfaction—leading  to  low  productivity  and  higher 
unit  costs.  The  low  level  of  funding  for  social  sectors  in  the  late  1990s,  especially  for  the 
nonsalary budget, led to further deterioration in the quality of social services. 
 
On 14 August 2001, the LG system replaced the old system of provincial administrations 
15. 
at  the  division,  district,  and  tehsil  levels.  The  new  system,  regulated  under  the  Punjab  Local 
Government  Ordinance  2001  (PLGO),  provides  for  much  more  autonomous  LGs  in  districts, 
tehsil  municipal  administrations  (TMAs),  in  towns  and  union  administrations  (UAs)  in  villages. 
The intent is to devolve political power and decentralize administrative and financial authority to 
accountable LGs for improved governance, effective delivery of social services, and transparent 
decision making through institutionalized participation of the people at the grassroots level. The 
new  system  is  designed  to  bring  decision  making  closer  to  beneficiaries  of  public  services; 
ensure citizens’ involvement and oversight in planning and implementation; and give a greater 
voice  to  women,  peasants,  laborers,  and  marginalized  population  groups.  Devolution  of 
administrative  and  financial  powers,  followed  by  the  appropriate  empowerment,  staffing,  and 
resource  allocation  to  LGs,  is  expected  to  deliver  better  public  services  like  health,  education, 
and  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS).  PG,  to  date,  has  issued  more  than  60  administrative 
orders and 16 consequential pieces of legislation for transfer of powers to LGs under the PLGO. 
 
16. 
Devolution  is,  however,  in  a  transition  phase  and  transfer  of  powers  is  still  continuing. 
The PG and LGs are clarifying their roles and responsibilities and devising mechanisms to build 
capacity  at  various  levels.  There  is  a  challenge  in  meeting  citizens’  expectations  on  the  one 
hand and filling large capacity gaps on the other. With a paradigm shift in the power structure, 
there  are  tensions  both  between  the  provincial-  and  local  government-elected  representatives 
and within LG tiers, which need to be carefully addressed through appropriate management of 
intergovernment relations. The capacity of LGs to undertake their new roles and responsibilities 
has to be strengthened. A number of initiatives are under way to improve the capacity of LGs 
under  the  Decentralization  Support  Program  (DSP),  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program 
(PRMP),  and  PG's  own  inputs.  While  these  efforts  are  in  the  right  direction,  they  need  to  be 
sustained in the medium term, particularly to help reduce the tensions between provincial and 
local offices.

3. 

Social Sector Financing 

 
17. 
Overall,  the  PG  lacks  sufficient  resources  to  meet  its  large  socioeconomic  needs  as 
reflected  in  its  MTBF.  Under  the  P-PRSP,  PG  has  committed  to  increase  the  pro-poor  social 
expenditures  by  another  40%  by  FY2006,  when  these  sectors  would  account  for  42%  of  the 
consolidated budget of the province. At present, provincial expenditures on all development and 
nondevelopment activities, including LG expenditures, are about 6.5% of provincial GDP. This 
amounts to less than $30 per capita for running the government, servicing debt, supporting LGs, 
maintaining infrastructure, and financing social services. Provinces, including Punjab, and LGs 
are heavily reliant on fiscal transfers from the Government. PG derives 80% of its revenues from 
federal transfers and 20% from its own revenues; both these revenue sources grew by 13–15% 
per annum in the last 5 years. However, the trend in revenue increase is not sufficient to finance 
Punjab’s  increased  expenditure  obligations  under  the  P-PRSP  and  the  cost  of  implementing 
devolution.  
 
18. 
In the social sectors, PG has undertaken various initiatives to improve their performance. 
There is substantial increase in social sector allocations. Expenditures on education, health, and 
WSS  services  collectively  made  up  about  32%  of  total  provincial  spending  during  FY2000/01 
through  FY2003/04.  These  expenditures  grew  roughly 
line  with  overall  provincial 
expenditures  during  this  period  (8.6%  per  annum).  Growth  rates,  however,  varied  between 
sectors—education  at  12.1%  per  annum,  health  at  7.7%  per  annum,  and  WSS  at  8.6%  per 
annum.  Allocations  to  the  three  sectors  increased  substantially  in  FY2004/05  in  line  with  P-
PRSP—education at 27.2%, health at 40.8%, and WSS at 123.9%,9 with an overall increase of 
31.6%.  Overall,  the  share  of  these  social  sectors  in  the  provincial  budget  rose  to  35.8%.  The 
2004/05 budget provided a generous increase for the nonsalary budget. 
 
19. 
PG  negotiated  the  PRMP  with  ADB  in  September  2003  to  strengthen  its  finances, 
realign  governance  institutions  for  pro-poor  service  delivery,  and  increase  opportunities  for 
income  and  growth  in  the  private  sector.  It  proposes  to  create  fiscal  space  by  developing  a 
broad-based tax structure, rationalizing expenditure and management functions, and providing 
for labor market interventions to support the private sector. The proposed levels of funding for 
social  sectors,  over  one  third  of  the  total  expenditures,  appear  sustainable  if  the  PRMP  is

increase  in  the  provincial  share  of  federal  transfers  under  the  new  National  Finance 
Commission  award.  PG’s  commitment  to  enhance  social  sector  allocations,  improve  social 
indicators,  and  reduce  poverty  of  opportunity  is  supported  by  assistance  that  includes  the 
Punjab Education Sector Reform Program (PESRP) supported by the World Bank, and the two 
health and two WSS projects supported by ADB.10

Social Sector Development 

 
20. 
The  social  sectors  are  human  resource  intensive,  have  a  wide  infrastructure,  and 
consume nearly 36% of public sector expenditure. The urban-based facilities often work beyond 
their  capacity  because  of  better  quality  services,  large  and  rising  population  to  serve,  higher 
literacy rates and awareness of consumers, and better communication links. While urban areas 
offer  a  different  set  of  challenges  and  provide  options  for  service  delivery,  rural  facilities  are 
scattered,  poorly  staffed,  and  underutilized.  Rural  facilities  have  inadequate  nonsalary 
operational  budgets,  many  unfilled  vacancies  (particularly  in  disadvantaged  locations),  low 
quality  of  services  because  of  poor  management  and  weak  monitoring  arrangements,  limited 
access for women, limited user and community involvement, and poor public accountability.

26.

encouraging  in  Pakistan.  Under  5,  infant,  and  maternal  mortality  rates  are  unacceptably  high;

Objectives and Scope 

 
A. 
 
45. 
The overall goal of PDSSP is to achieve progress on MDGs related to poverty, gender, 
education, health, and WSS. The program objective is to strengthen devolved social services for 
a more equitable, efficient, effective, and sustainable delivery of social services in line with the 
PLGO. In order to achieve the goal and objective, it will be necessary to (i) increase funding to 
social  sectors  to  expand  access  to  health  services,18  especially  for  women  and  children, 
increase  school  enrollment  rates,  and  improve  access  to  WSS  facilities;  (ii) move  away  from 
provincially-driven  to  demand-driven  programs  that  are  identified  and  implemented  by  LGs  in 
line  with  P-PRSP,  MTBF  and  provincial  strategic  plans  and  guidelines  to  achieve  MDGs;  and 
(iii) enhance the capacity of LGs to assume new roles and responsibilities in social services as 
envisaged  under  the  PLGO,  including  participatory  planning,  implementation,  and  monitoring 
and evaluation.  
 
46.

strengthening of planning processes, further devolution of administrative and financial powers to 
LGs,  empowerment  of  LG  monitoring  committees,  empowerment  of  females,  and  transfer  of 
additional  funds  to  LGs  to  improve  the  equity  and  quality  of  social  services.  The  road  map  to 
move  from  the  current  stage  to  the  next  stage  is  articulated  in  the  three  principal  policy 
outcomes  that  PDSSP  seeks  to  support:  (i) realigning  intergovernment  relations  to  support 
devolved  social  services,  (ii) rationalizing  and  setting  minimum  standards  for  social  services, 
(iii) strengthening  public  accountability  mechanisms  and  promoting  public-private 
and 
partnership (PPP).

Gender  

 
98. 
Universal primary education and a focus on expanding middle education will benefit girls 
whose enrollment still remains low. Higher enrollment of girls in primary and middle education 
will  allow  more  girls  to  undertake  secondary  education,  which  is  strongly  associated  with 
reduction  in  infant  and  child  mortality  in  rural  areas.  Improved  access  to  and  management  of 
pregnancy-related emergencies will not only help in lowering maternal mortality, but also help in 
breaking the chain of family catastrophes. The implementation of the GRAP  (Appendix 10) will 
increase access to social services by women. The implementation of the GRAP will be another 
window for mainstreaming women in the government structure and local bodies and improve the 
participation of women at management and decision-making levels. 
 

3. 

Institutional Impact 

 
99. 
PDSSP  envisions  institutional  reforms  to  strengthen  the  newly  established  LG  system. 
The  reforms  will  institutionalize  improved  governance,  access  to  information,  and  citizens’ 
participation  in  planning  of  social  services  to  help  improve  service  delivery.  PDSSP  will 
strengthen the compact between policy makers (PG and LGs), service providers (LGs and their 
staff),  and  consumers  (communities)  to  make  social  services  more  accountable  to  the 
communities  they  serve,  especially  the  disadvantaged  and  deprived  communities.  The

participation.  PDSSP  interventions  will  also  rationalize  institutional  structures  for  social  sector

4. 

Economic and Poverty Impact 

 
100.  The social sectors will benefit from PDSSP through conditional grants. These grants are 
in  addition  to  social  sector  investments  already  planned  by  PG  and  LGs.  The  additional 
resource  envelope  is  mainly  focused  on  the  poor  and  vulnerable  through  delivery  of  essential 
pro-poor  services.  The  expected  outputs  from  enhanced  investments  will  lead  to  human 
development  by  improving  basic  health  and  education,  which  in  turn  will  provide  impetus  to 
accelerate  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty.  In  addition,  by  ensuring  a  focus  on  pro-poor 
social sector investments, the program loans also addresse important concerns of bridging wide 
gaps  in  income-based  social  development.  Indirectly,  better  governance  and  the  likely  social 
development  will  have  a  strong  positive  impact  on  poverty  reduction.  A  summary  poverty  and 
social analysis is in Supplementary Appendix H.  
 

5. 

Environmental Aspects 

 
101.  PDSSP  is  classified  as  environmental  category  B  due  to  issues  related  to  absence  of 
service  standards  for  collection  and  disposal  of  hazardous  and  infectious  medical  waste,  and 
environmental  hazards  resulting  from  poor  disposal  systems  for  sewage  and  solid  waste. 
PDSSP includes interventions related to improving the environmental aspects over the medium 
term through developing and implementing standard procedures and protocols for collection and 
disposal of hazardous wastes. PDSSP will recruit two consultants, one for medical wastes and 
the other for WSS waste management, to provide TA to DGs and program TMAs to develop and 
implement standard operating procedures for disposal of hazardous and infectious waste, and 
support  training  of  related  staff.  The  environmental  assessment  summary  is  in  Supplementary 
Appendix I.

2. 

Governance Risks 

 
103.  A major focus of PDSSP is to improve social sector governance and lead to transparent 
and objective decision making to minimize rent seeking. As a result, there is a risk that reform 

 
 

 

 

 24

 

implementation  might  be  delayed  or  undermined  by  vested  interests.  PDSSP  includes  the 
following  risk  mitigation  measures:  building  stakeholder  ownership  during  the  program  design 
and implementation stages; establishing program oversight mechanisms including participation 
of  LG  council  committees;  and  ensuring  synergy  with  other  reform  programs  such  as  PRMP, 
DSP, and PESRP.  
 

3. 

Capacity Constraints 

 
104.  Devolution of delivery of social sector services to LGs presents both a challenge and an 
opportunity.  While  devolution  moves  social  sector  planning,  implementation,  and  monitoring 
closer  to  beneficiaries,  it  also  introduces  an  additional  element  of  commitment  and  capacity 
problems  in  terms  of  delivery.  At  present,  the  financial,  managerial  and  technical  capacity  of 
LGs  is  limited  and  there  would  be  limitations  in  effectively  spending  additional  funds.  LGs,  on 
the other hand, are best positioned to ensure that new interventions are designed and located 
appropriately  and  involve  beneficiaries  in  the  design  of  social  services  and  user  fees.  These 
risks will be mitigated by timely and appropriately designed capacity-building activities that will 
be financed through the TA component.   
 

4. 

Macroeconomic and External Risks 

 
105.  PG  has  faced  serious  budget  deficits  in  the  past,  and  has  a  history  of  poor  revenue 
collection. There were serious budget cuts for the social sectors during the 1990s, resulting in 
deteriorating  quality  of  social  services  and  stagnating  enrollment  rates.  According  to  the 
projections  given  in  the  P-PRSP,  PG  has  committed  to  substantially  enhancing  social  sector 
allocations  in  the  coming  3  years,  with  an  average  increase  of  16%  for  health,  12%  for 
education,  and  67%  for  WSS.21  These  additional  commitments  are  subject  to  the  improved 
performance of the economy as a whole.  
 
106.  Pakistan has strengthened its economic performance considerably over the last 3 years. 
The Government has put in place a consistent economic management strategy that is based on 
fiscal stabilization and debt reduction to mitigate macroeconomic vulnerabilities. In FY2003/04, 
the economy recorded a GDP growth rate of 6.4% as against 5.1% in 2002/03, the fiscal deficit 
has  come  down  to  3.3%  of  GDP  compared  with  an  average  of  7.0%  in  the  1990s,  and  the 
poverty  rate  has  decreased  by  4.2%.22  With  ongoing  reforms  and  some  improvement  in  the 
investment  rate,  economic  growth  may  improve  further.  However,  the  country’s  political  and 
economic stability is dependent on geopolitical developments in the region, especially peaceful 
relations with neighbors such as India and Afghanistan.

24. 
Current Status. The major source of drinking water in Punjab is groundwater. However 
in  26  districts,  there  are  significant  pockets  of  water  scarcity  or  brackish  subsoil  water  where 
about 10,000 villages are located. In eight districts and some pockets in other districts, subsoil 
water is of good quality and easily accessible. About 94% of households have a water source 
inside  the  house,  of  which  76%  get  water  from  a  handmotor  pump  and  18%  from  the  public 
water supply system. The remaining 6% use unsafe water from shallow wells, rivers, or canals 
that are often located at a considerable distance, with the burden of fetching water largely falling 
on women. Treatment of public water supplies is undertaken at only a few places and even that 
is on a limited scale; there is no treatment of water at the household level either, except in a few 
urban households. The infrastructure for water supply and sanitation (WSS) was developed in 
the past without analyzing the feasibility and affordability of operation and maintenance (O&M) 
costs.  As  a  result,  several  hundred  poorly  designed,  and  financially  and  institutionally 
unsustainable  rural  water  supply  schemes  have  been  abandoned.  The  experience  shows  that 
rural  communities  can  only  maintain  low-cost  water  supply  schemes  using  simple  technology, 
and when these schemes are planned and developed with their participation.  
 
25. 
Around  68%  of  rural  and  7%  of  urban  households  have  no  toilet  facility.  The  lack  of 
access  by  the  poor  to  a  flush  latrine  is  a  major  public  health  concern  as  it  contributes  to  the 
spread of waterborne and food-borne diseases. Over 42% of households are not connected to a 
drainage  system,  and  nearly  the  same  percentage  of  households  are  connected  to  an  open 
drain.  The  underground  or  covered  drainage  system  is  only  available  to  38%  of  urban 
households.  The  position  of  garbage  disposal  is  even  worse.  Only  6%  of  all  households  have 
access to a municipal garbage collection system, representing 19% of urban households. About 
12% of households have established a “private” system for garbage collection. 
 
26. 
Key  Issues.  Prior  to  devolution,  the  Public  Health  Engineering  Department  (PHED)  in 
rural areas and towns, and the water and sanitation agencies (WASAs) in cities with 5 million-
plus  populations  were  the  main  agencies  responsible  for  planning  and  implementing  all 
provincial  government-financed  major  investment  projects.  In  addition,  the  municipalities 
implemented  minor  investments  largely  from  their  own  resources.  Under  the  PLGO,  all 
municipal functions, including WSS, were assigned to the TMA, along with staff devolved from 
the  Local  Government  and  Rural  Development  (LG&RD)  Department,  Health  and  Population 
Policy  Department,  and  PHED.  While  PHED  transferred  its  field  staff  to  the  TMAs,  it  has 
continued  its  links  with  the  sector  through  retaining  staff  in  four  regional  units  and  at  the 
provincial  level,  and  through  assigning  to  itself  powers  of  approval  of  WSS  projects  costing 
more than PRs5 million. The PHED is also implementing an ADB-financed WSS project through 
which it is exercising responsibilities devolved to the TMAs under the PLGO.

Principles of Use of Funds 

A. 
 
The funds available under the Program serve the twin purposes of acting as an incentive 
1. 
for different tiers of the Government to undertake and sustain policy actions, as well providing 
some  fiscal  support  for  local  governments  (LGs)  to  engage  in  social  sector  delivery 
improvements.  By  themselves,  the  funds  are  neither  sufficient  to  finance  any  specific  gaps  in 
the social sectors, nor are they meant to act as investments funds alone. The definitions of the 
scope of use of these funds, as well as the institutional mechanisms through which they are to 
be used by the local governments, thus assume paramount importance. Within the overarching 
framework of the Program and generally following the principle of finance following function, the 
funds would be proposed for use in a manner that supports and leads to the achievement of the 
program  goals  and  objectives  and  the  specific  actions  outlined  in  the  policy  matrix  for  the 
Program.  While  aiming  to  provide  optimal  flexibility  to  the  LGs  to  enable  efficient  choices  for 
investments aimed at improving social services, the proposed use of funds would at the same 
time adopt mechanisms that enable the Punjab Government (PG) to ensure that the processes 
of targeted, accountable, and participatory sector planning at the LG level are strengthened and 
the  investments  are  pro-poor  and  gender-sensitive.  The  distribution  of  funds  proposed  would 
provide for clear, predictable, and transparent funding to LGs. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  counterpart  funds  generated  by  the  Program  will  be  used  to  finance  a  package  of 
policy reforms. The distribution of program funds need to be based on a set of clear, objective, 
and  relevant  criteria  that  take  into  account  the  sector  focus  of  the  Program  and  the  specific 
elements  of  the  policy  matrix,  so  as  to  ensure  that  there  is  a  fit  between  the  funding  and  the 
policy actions in a manner that leads to the achievement of the program objectives. In arriving at 
these distribution criteria, a number of aspects need to be considered, including the following. 
 
3. 
Sector  Distribution.  Given  the  availability  of  funds  in  the  social  sectors  from  both  the 
Government’s own resources, as well as from external assistance agencies, and also in view of 
the priorities of the government of Punjab and financing gaps identified, it is proposed that the 
program funds be distributed among the health, education, and water and sanitation sectors in 
the ratio of 65:17:18. The district governments (DGs) will receive 82% of all program funds for 
health and education and the tehsil (town) municipal administrations (TMAs) will receive 18%. 
 
4. 
Fund  for  Promoting  Public-Private  Partnerships  (PPPs).  In  order  to  promote  PPPs 
for  improving  social  services  in  terms  of  access,  delivery  or  monitoring,  it  is  proposed  to 
apportion  some  program  funds  to  be  used  as  a  fund  for  PPPs.  In  line  with  the  Punjab  Local 
Government Ordinance 2001 (PLGO 2001), which calls for allocating 25% of the total budget for 
engagement  with  citizen  community  boards  (CCBs),  it  is  proposed  that  the  DGs  and  program 
TMAs also apportion 25% of funds for purposes of PPPs. However, the mechanism for use of

conditional  upon  equity  financing  from  partners  from  the  private  sector  in  the  PPP.  This  PPP 
fund  will  be  available  for  use  by  all  community-based  organizations  (CBOs),  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), CCBs, school councils (SCs), patient welfare associations (PWAs), and 
private  sector  firms,  subject  to  their  meeting  the  basic  eligibility  criteria  for  participation,  to  be 
developed under the Program.

Contribution of sectors/subsectors to reduce poverty in Pakistan (Punjab province) 
 
The decade of 1990s in Pakistan witnessed increasing incidence of poverty. The reason for increasing poverty is due 
to  a  decade  long  slowdown  in  economic  growth,  decline  in  public  and  private  investments,  increase  in  fiscal  and 
current  account  deficits,  and  rapid  debt  accumulation.  In  late  2000,  the  Government  of  Pakistan  adopted  Interim 
Poverty Reduction Strategy, which was updated in 2003. The core elements of the strategy are to engender growth, 
improve human development and governance, and reduce vulnerability of the poor to shocks.  
 
Punjab as the largest province of Pakistan, faces two challenges of reviving economic growth and reducing poverty. 
Incidence of poverty in the province is around 34.1%, which was 28.2% in 1993/94. The urban-rural gap is significant 
and poverty increased more rapidly in rural areas than in the urban areas from 31.9% in 1993/94 to 37.0% in 2001/02. 
The incidence of poverty is much higher in southern Punjab. In southern Punjab, the level of economic development 
and income is lower than in northern Punjab. While urban areas in northern Punjab had the lowest level of poverty 
in the country (13%), southern Punjab showed the highest level of urban poverty in Pakistan (35% in 1999, up from 28% 
in  1993).  In  northern  Punjab  a  great  deal  of  development  efforts  and  investments,  especially  industrial 
investments, has been concentrated in recent years.  
 
Since  2002/03,  the  poverty  reduction  strategy  and  program  of  the  Government  of  Punjab  has  made  a  major 
departure from the past in terms of increased financing for the social sectors and taking initiatives to improve public 
sector  governance.  The  strengthening  of  devolution  of  the  social  services  through  Punjab’s  Local  Government 
Ordinance  2001  (PLGO)  is  well  advanced  than  other  provinces.  So  far  16  consequential  pieces  of  legislations  have 
been passed to strengthen the local government system. According to the Local Government Ordinance, education up 
to  secondary  level,  primary  health,  and  referral  services  up  to  district  hospitals  have  been  devolved  to  the  district 
governments,  while  tehsil  (town)  municipal  administrations  are  made  responsible  for  water  supply  and  sanitation 
sector as  part  of municipal services. The local government services, as  conceived,  are expected to  improve  quality, 
efficiency,  and  accountability  of  social  services  through  improved  resource  allocation,  participatory  decision  making, 
and by solving problems using local solutions. 
 
The poverty partnership agreement between the Government of Pakistan and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
reflects  the  Government's  vision  for  poverty  reduction  and  improving  the  quality  and  access  of  social  services, 
especially  for  the  poor.  The  Government  has  agreed  that  long-term  poverty  reduction  requires  focus  on  good 
governance,  increased  allocation  of  funds  for  social  sectors,  and  improving  basic  social  services  to  enhance 
human  development.  ADB  supports  governance  reforms  through  the  Decentralization  Support  Program  and 
other  ongoing sector programs and  projects undertaken by the Government. The  goal of the Punjab Devolved 
Social  Services  Program  (PDSSP) 
to  achieve  Millennium 
Development  Goals  (MDGs)  related  to  poverty,  gender,  education,  health,  water  and  sanitation.  Specifically,

37.0% in 2001/02. The poverty in Punjab is described in broader terms of income,  consumption,  social  services  and 
basic needs of urban and rural population. A study on district profile ranked 34 districts of Punjab, and the findings of 
the study suggest that out of the total  districts, 10  districts  have  been  classified  as  highly  deprived  in  descending

Some  of  the  characteristics  of  the  rural  poverty  are:  (i)  dependence  on  daily  wage  labor  in  agriculture  and 
nonagricultural activities, brick kiln, petty vending, etc; (ii) high indebtedness to private money lenders; (iii) no land or 
any other assets; (iv) lack of access government services (health, education, water); and (v) no voice and no role in 
decision making in the community.  
 
In Punjab inequalities of provision of social services exist among the households from different social and economic 
conditions. For example literacy rate is higher for higher income group than the lower income group. Services of health 
facilities are available to the higher and middle-income group than the lower income group and the poor. That the poor 
lack access to basic social services is not always due to lack of established social service facilities, but often because 
of the service provider attitudes toward them. Interviews with the poor people indicate that they are often discriminated 
and neglected by the service providers. For example, sometimes the health service provider of the government health 
facility does not attend the poor patient and if the poor get attended by the doctor, they do not get adequate or proper 
treatment and medicine.    
 
Illiteracy is also positively correlated with poverty. The poverty levels are higher in households where the head of the 
household  is  illiterate.  Literacy  ratio  and  per  pupil  expenditure  of  primary  and  secondary  education  is  substantially 
higher in urban areas than rural areas and among households in the highest income quintile compared to households 
in the lowest income quintile. Gross enrollment rates (GERs) at primary level in Punjab are 69% for females and 84% 
for  males  and  net  primary  enrollment  rates  (NERs)  are  43%  for  females  and  47%  for  males.  Primary  level  GERs 
among the first income  quintile are 44% for  females and  61%  for males, while in the fifth quintile they  are 97% and 
117%, respectively. Literacy rates for population 10 years and above are 36% for females and 57% for males. GERs 
at middle level are 43% for females and 46% for males. At secondary level, GERs are 34% for females and 55% for 
males. Dropout rates of children 15–19 years were much higher among girls (33%) than boys (24.45%). 
 
The social sector indicators are generally poor compared to countries with similar per capita income. The total fertility 
rate is currently 4.8 and contraceptive prevalence rate is estimated at 27.6%. The maternal mortality ratio per 100,000 
live  births  is  in  the  range  of  500.  Nearly  11%  of  children  die  before  reaching  their  fifth  birthday.  Among  those  who 
survive,  one  quarter  do  not  go  to  school.  Currently  there  are  about  4  million  malnourished  children  in  Punjab,  and 
about a third of all pregnant women are estimated to have iron deficiency anemia. Over 35% of children under the age 
of 5 years are short for their age; over 10% are under weight for their age and over half are anemic.  
 
During  the  1990s,  the  government  of  Punjab  implemented  Social  Action  Program  (SAP)  to  improve  delivery  and 
governance  of  social  services.  The  SAP  results  are  mixed.  A  combination  of  factors  such  as  weak  planning, 
implementation  strategies,  lack  of  social  mobilization  activities,  planning  at  the  community  level,  lack  of  transparent 
process in financing and management etc. influenced the outcome of the SAP and did not bring the desired results. In 
addition  to  the  SAP,  other  social  sector  and  poverty  programs  brought  limited  impact  on  poverty  reduction  and  in 
providing access to social services to the poor and women. Limited success of social service delivery is due to several 
factors. Following observations are made during the field visits to Guzrat and Mandi Bahauddin: (i) lack of clarity on 
role and responsibilities of the officials from different line agencies and the different tier of the local government under 
PLGO 2001; (ii) intergovernment relationships are not fully realized and practiced by the officials as described under 
different notifications; (iii) in equitable and inefficient management and resource allocation for district, tehsil, and union 
council  level;  (iv)  schools  and  health  facilities  are  without  teachers,  doctors,  and  paramedics;  (v)  absenteeism  of 
service providers in the assigned duty station; and (vi) service facilities are not aligned to provide services to the poor 
and the women.  
 
The  proposed  PDSSP  plans  to  contribute  to  these  objectives  by  introducing  rational  policy  reforms,  building 
institutional and human resource capacity of social service agencies, quality of social services, and flexible financing 
for the devolved social services. The specific interventions include: (i) development of operational manuals for service 
agencies  for  better  planning;  (ii)  capacity  building  of  the  officials  of  the  service  agencies,  local  government  and  the 
elected  representatives  of  the  union  councils  and  nazims  of  the  three  tiers  of  local  government;  (iii)  use  of  citizen 
charters,  display  of  development  funds,  development  projects/programs  for  citizens  review  and  suggestion,  in  the 
district council, tehsil, union council, and  social service facility boards; (iv) awareness raising activities for the service 
providers  to  develop  pro-poor  and  pro-gender  social  service  delivery  mechanism;  and  (v)  improving  public-private 
partnership mechanisms for developing innovative projects on  social  services  for  the  local  communities,  including 
women and the poor. An important intervention under the PDSSP is to target poor and vulnerable population groups 
by designing pro-poor services, especially for the rural population and the deprived districts.
